Situation1: Include each other in social activities and outings when possible.
Expectation2: Provide spiritual guidance and counseling to individuals in need
Situation2: A member of the community has scheduled an appointment to discuss a persistent personal struggle.
Story: My phone buzzed with a message from my sister: “We’re all going to the lake this afternoon. You have to come!” I could almost hear her laughter, see the rest of the family gathered, waiting for me to join. As her brother, I knew how much it meant to her that I show up, that I be present, not just in name but in spirit—building the kind of mutual respect we’d promised each other after our parents passed. But as I glanced at my calendar, my heart sank. At the same time, I had an appointment with Mrs. Carter, a member of my congregation who had finally found the courage to seek help for a struggle she’d kept hidden for years. As her priest, I was expected to be there, to listen, to offer guidance and comfort. The weight of both roles pressed on me—my family’s hope for togetherness, and my community’s need for support. I sat in my office, torn, the laughter of my family echoing in my mind while the silent plea of Mrs. Carter lingered in my heart, unsure which path to take.
